awd_titl_txt: NSFGEO-NERC: Collaborative Research: Linking geophysics and volcanic gas measurements to constrain the transcrustal magmatic system at the Altiplano-Puna Deformation Anomaly
awd_abstract_narration:
The path that magma takes through the crust is not well understood -- where is magma stored and under what conditions will it erupt? While this question is of fundamental scientific interest, it is also directly related to understanding the hazard posed by volcanic systems that are showing signs of activity and unrest. This project seeks to understand the cause of unrest and the architecture of the magma storage system within the central Andes, home to the world's largest geophysically imaged zone of silicic partial melt, the Altiplano-Puna Magma (or Mush) Body (APMB).  This project involves scientists in the USA, United Kingdom, and Bolivia to collect new field measurements (gravity, ground deformation, seismic, gas flux and composition) at Uturuncu volcano, Bolivia and develop numerical models of the volcano motivated by the new data.  In particular, the new data will add to the limited understand of the background activity at restless volcanoes that is necessary to better assess the hazard of future volcanic unrest -- what is normal activity and what should cause concern?

There is a new emerging paradigm of a transcrustal magmatic system (TCMS) where magma storage and differentiation occurs at several locations throughout the entire crustal column. This conceptual revolution is being driven by petrological, geochronological, and geochemical studies of magma storage conditions that show (1) many large eruptions tap multiple melt sources, (2) large melt bodies are probably transient features, (3) crystals carried by the transporting melt have been stored at a range of pressures and temperatures. A key location to assess and refine models of currently active TCMS is at the APMB, where a large ground deformation pattern 150 km in diameter lasting several decades has been observed centered on Uturuncu volcano, Bolivia. By collecting and analyzing new interdisciplinary field measurements (gravity, ground deformation, seismic, gas flux and composition) and developing 3D numerical models, this proposal will answer several outstanding questions about the nature of TCMS at the APMB: 1. What is the cause of deformation in the midcrust at the APMB: a magmatic diapir, cyclic up and down movements from magma mush reorganization involving magma and/or volatiles, or something else? 2. What is the nature of a shallow-seated conductivity anomaly -- to what extent is it partial melt, a hydrothermal brine reservoir, or a mature ore body? 3. What is the flux of volatiles through the TCMS? 4. How important is crustal anisotropy in the interpretation of the subsurface magma plumbing architecture?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Uturuncu volcano in southwestern Bolivia shows several signs of current activity: earthquakes, ground deformation, and thermal and gas emissions even though it has not erupted in more than 250,000 years.

 

Broader impacts: Although Bolivia has 12 potentially active volcanoes, there are no seismic stations near the volcanoes in southwest Bolivia or other geophysical or geochemical monitoring of these volcanoes. Thus, the data collected in this project add to the limited understand of the background earthquake activity at the volcanoes that is necessary to better assess the hazard of future volcanic unrest -- what is normal activity and what should cause concern?  This project promoted international collaboration between scientists from multiple institutions in the USA, United Kingdom, and Bolivia.

 

Intellectural Merit: This project involved analysis of satellite observations, historical seismic data, and new field measurements in Bolivia including measurements of gravity, ground deformation, seismic data and gas flux and composition, as well as developments of numerical models of the volcano motivated by the new data. We find that while ground uplift centered on Uturuncu has been ongoing since the 1960s, in the last ten years or so, the maximum rate of uplift has diminished to 3 mm/year and a small region of subsidence near the volcano occurred from 2014-2017.  More than 2300 earthquakes have been located at Uturuncu volcano between 2009-2012 by local seismic networks.  Most of the earthquakes are volcano-tectonic and can be related to small, unmapped faults.  The involvement of fluids in the faulting is suggested both by the fact that many earthquakes are triggered by the passage of telseismic waves for the 2010 Mw Maule earthquake in Chile as well as a b-value of 1.44. A gap in seismicity between about 14 and 22 km below the surface is interpreted to be part of a zone of partial melt called the Altiplano-Puna Mush Body (APMB) that has been imaged by several geophysical methods.  New seismic data were collected from six seismometers installed at Uturuncu between 2018-2022 -- analysis of these data are ongoing.  Measurements of changes in the gravity field near Uturuncu between 2010 and 2018 show a decrease of up to -30 mGal.  After accounting for the gravity change due to vertical ground displacements constrained by InSAR and GNSS observations, a change in the subsurface density is required to explain the data Based on the measurements of earthquake characteristics and changes in gravity, there is evidence that subsurface fluid movements and active brine layers cause much of the current shallow activity at Uturuncu. 

 

Given the inferred high subsurface temperatures and fluid movements, we suggest that the region around Uturuncu might be a good development target for geothermal energy and could possibly contain mineral deposits.  However, the shallow manifestations of activity do not reveal the presence of large amounts of partially molten rock.   While current data do not suggest an imminent eruption of the volcano, we encourage continued monitoring.

 


Last Modified: 06/06/2023
Modified by: Matthew E Pritchard

Images (1 of )
  • (Left) Location of Uturuncu volcano in southwestern Bolivia. (right) Photograph of Uturuncu from the northwest (From: Tom Fournier).
    Matt Pritchard and Tom Fournier
    Copyrighted
    Matthew E Pritchard
    Uturuncu Volcano
  • Uplift time series from Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar 1992-2020 and the Global Navigation Satellite System from 2010-2020 near Uturuncu, updated from Lau et al., (2018). Inset is a velocity map from Henderson and Pritchard (2017).
    Elizabeth Eiden and collaborators
    Copyrighted
    Matthew E Pritchard
    Time series of ground deformation at Uturuncu volcano (1992-2022)
